thread.title: Beware 30-Year Treasury Bonds Now That Greece Is Out of the Way
thread.title_full: Beware 30-Year Treasury Bonds Now That Greece Is Out of the Way - Bloomberg Business

author: Wes Goodman
title: Beware 30-Year Treasury Bonds Now That Greece Is Out of the Way
text:
Losses are mounting in 30-year Treasuries as the most volatile government bonds head for their fourth straight monthly decline.
Demand for the haven of U.S. government debt is waning now that Greece has reached an agreement with its creditors. Bond market metrics indicate the American economy is growing fast enough to convince the Federal Reserve to end its zero-interest rate policy set during the financial crisis of 2008, though an increase may not come until 2016.
Thirty-year Treasuries, known as long bonds, are down 1.8 percent in July, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch indexes. They’ve tumbled 12 percent since the end of March. By comparison the broader Treasury market has fallen 2.2 percent in the period. With investors demanding more compensation to buy longer-maturity debt, the yield is approaching the highest level in nine months.
“The U.S. economy looks to be good, and we’re seeing a lot of the risk around Europe dissipated over the last 24 hours,” said Peter Jolly, head of research in Sydney at National Australia Bank Ltd., the nation’s largest as measured by assets. “We’re back to looking at fundamentals.”
Long bonds had a respite Tuesday, with the yield falling two basis points to 3.22 percent at 11:22 a.m. in Tokyo, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The 3 percent security due May 2045 rose 11/32, or $3.44 per $1,000 face amount, to 95 27/32. The yield climbed to 3.25 percent Monday, within a basis point of the highest level since September.
Benchmark 10-year yields dropped one basis point on Tuesday to 2.44 percent.
Bond Focus Thirty-year bonds tend to react more to the long-term growth outlook. Investors holding shorter debt have the assurance they will get their money back sooner when the securities mature.
Treasuries slid Monday as Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and European creditors agreed to a rescue plan for the nation, curtailing demand for the safest securities.
The Fed will probably raise interest rates in about six months, according to a Morgan Stanley index based on futures trading. As recently as July 8, the gauge was indicating an increase would not happen for almost eight months.
The U.S. employment rate fell to a seven-year low of 5.3 percent in June. Policy makers have kept their benchmark at almost zero since December 2008 to support the economy during the recession that began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009.
